page.title: 07Industry in Rogate
page.content: The beer is made with male hops from Kent and Herefordshire.Water, barley and malted yeast is added but no other secret ingredients. All this is boiled up in a large tub, before being put through a sieve or strainer. The debris is sold off by the sack full for garden use. The liquid then spends the next five days in a cooler. This fermentation vessel can hold 300 gallons. When ready the beer is put into casks which are called Pin for half a gallon or Firkin 9 gallons or Kilderkin 18 gallons. The Firkin costs Â£60 and the Kilderkin Â£90 to buy. Customs and Excise officers regularly inspect the brewing process to check on the amount being made and the strength of the alcohol. They sometimes visit at night as they have a key.
